_exec_summary.SummaryText:
KCP&L - LaCygne Generating Station, LaCygne KS 66040


The Kansas City Power & Light (KCP&L) Company LaCygne Generating Station maintains one substance, anhydrous ammonia, on site in amounts exceeding the Risk Management Program (RMP) thershold quantities.

Anhydrous ammonia will be used at the LaCygne Generating Station as an air pollution control additive, to reduce the nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions to the atmosphere from the Unit #1 boiler with a selective catalytic reduction (SCR) device.

Plant Description

The LaCygne Generating Station is located in LaCygne, Kansas at 25166 E. 2200 Road.   The facility is situated south-east of LaCygne  Lake.  The property surrounding the LaCygne Station is rural.

Ammonia System Description

The ammonia storage tanks are designed to be filled by a tanker truck at a dedicated loading station.  For the NOx control systems, ammonia vapors will be drawn from the tanks, regulated for pressure, mixed with air, and injected into the boiler flue within the ammonia injection grid.  In combination with the catalyst in the selective catalytic reduction unit, nitrogen oxides will be reacted and emissions of the pollutant will be reduced.

Process Hazard Assessment (PHA)

Process hazard assessments were performed using a "What If" type analysis for the Unit #1 ammonia system.  This analysis utilizes a brainstorming approach, in which a team of people familiar with the process asks questions about possible undesirable events.  The "What If" analysis results in a listing of undesirable events with their consequences, safeguards, and  recommendations for risk reduction.  Comments and recommendations are summarized in the Process Hazard assessment section of the Risk Management Program.

Prevention System

The LaCygne Generating Station will have operation, maintenance, and inspection procedures for the anhydrous ammonia system.  There will be Operation and Maintenance manuals for each major piece of equipment,and personnel will receive tra

ining before being allowed to work on the systems.

The ammonia systems will be visually inspected on a periodic basis.  Standard operating procedures (SOPs) for startup, shutdown, normal operation and emergency operation of the ammonia storage systems will be in place when operation begins.  The SOPs wlil be written and posted in appropriate areas.  Personnel will be trained annually on safety concerns and general operation procedures as well as emergency procedures.

Ammonia sensors and alarms are in place to detect an ammonia release.  A fogging system to mitigate the impact of a release is in place.

Emergency Response Plan

KCP&L will respond to ammonia releated emergencies by notifying the Local Emergency Planning Commission and by evacuating its personnel, when needed.

Five Year Accident History

The LaCygne Generating Station has no ammonia releases in the past five years which need to be reported in the five year accident history.
